dialogs.original: Wheres Potpan, that he helps not to take away? He shift a trencher? He scrape a trencher!
dialogs.translated: Wheres Potpan, whos not helping us clear the table? Has he even moved or scraped a plate?

dialogs.original: When good manners shall lie all in one or two mens hands, and they unwashed too, tis a foul thing.
dialogs.translated: When all the good manners are owned by just one or two men, and even those two are dirty, its a bad thing.

dialogs.original: Away with the joint-stools, remove the court-cupboard,look to the plate. Good thou, save me a piece of marchpane,   and, as thou loves me, let the porter let in Susan Grindstone and Nell.Antony and Potpan!
dialogs.translated: Clear away the stools, sideboards, and plates. My friend, save me a piece of marzipan, and if you love me, have the porter let in Susan Grindstone and Nell. Antony and Potpan!

dialogs.original: Ay, boy, ready.
dialogs.translated: Yes, boy, Im ready.

dialogs.original: You are looked for and called for, asked for and sought for, in the great chamber.
dialogs.translated: Youre being called for, asked after, and looked for in the great chamber.

dialogs.original: We cannot be here and there too. Cheerly, boys. Be briska while, and the longer liver take all.
dialogs.translated: We cant be both here and there at once! Be cheerful, boys. Be quick for a while, and may the longest lived take everything.

dialogs.original: Welcome, gentlemen! Ladies that have their toes    Unplagued with corns will walk a bout with you.    Ah, my mistresses! Which of you all    Will now deny to dance?   She that makes dainty,    She, Ill swear, hath corns. Am I come near ye now?    Welcome, gentlemen! I have seen the day    That I have worn a visor and could tell    A whispering tale in a fair ladys ear    Such as would please.   Tis gone, tis gone, tis gone.    You are welcome, gentlemen.Come, musicians, play.    [Music plays and they dance]    A hall, a hall, give room!And foot it, girls.    More light, you knaves! And turn the tables up,    And quench the fire. The room is grown too hot.    Ah, sirrah, this unlooked-for sport comes well.    Nay, sit, nay, sit, good cousin Capulet,    For you and I are past our dancing days.    How long is t now since last yourself and I    Were in a mask?
dialogs.translated: Welcome, gentlemen. All the ladies who arent suffering from corns on their feet will dance with you. Ha ha! My ladies, now which of you will refuse to dance now? If any of you acts shyly, Ill swear she has corns. Have I hit the mark? Welcome, gentlemen. Once there was a time when I could wear a mask and charm a girl by whispering a story in her ear. No more, no more, no more. You are welcome gentlemen. Come, musicians, play. [Music plays and they dance] Make room in the hall! Make room! Dance, girls.

dialogs.original: Byr Lady, thirty years.
dialogs.translated: By the Virgin Mary, Id swear thirty years.

dialogs.original: What, man, tis not so much, tis not so much.    Tis since the nuptials of Lucentio,    Come Pentecost as quickly as it will,    Some five and twenty years, and then we masked.
dialogs.translated: What, man? Its not been that long, not that long. It was at Lucentios wedding. No matter how quickly the years fly by, its been just twenty-five years since we last wore masks.

dialogs.original: Tis more, tis more. His son is elder, sir.His son is thirty.
dialogs.translated: Longer, longer. Lucentios son is older than that, sir. Hes thirty.

dialogs.original: Will you tell me that?His son was but a ward two years ago.
dialogs.translated: How can you say that? His son was still a minor two years ago.

dialogs.original: [To a SERVINGMAN]  What lady is that which doth enrich the handOf yonder knight?
dialogs.translated: [To a SERVINGMAN] Who is that girl on the arm of that man over there?

dialogs.original: I know not, sir.
dialogs.translated: I dont know, sir.

dialogs.original: Oh, she doth teach the torches to burn bright!    It seems she hangs upon the cheek of night    Like a rich jewel in an Ethiopes ear,    Beauty too rich for use, for earth too dear.    So shows a snowy dove trooping with crows    As yonder lady oer her fellows shows.    The measure done, Ill watch her place of stand,    And, touching hers, make blessèd my rude hand.    Did my heart love till now? Forswear it, sight!    For I neer saw true beauty till this night.
dialogs.translated: Oh, she teaches the torches to burn bright! She glows in the darkness like a jewel in the ear of an African. Her beauty is too good to be used and worn, too precious for this world. Like a white dove in a flock of crows, she surpasses all the other women. When this dance ends, Ill note where she stands, and then Ill touch her hand and thereby bless my ugly one. Did I ever love anyone before this moment? Renounce that love, my eyes! I never saw true beauty until this night.

dialogs.original: This, by his voice, should be a Montague.    [To his PAGE]   Fetch me my rapier, boy.    What, dares the slave    Come hither, covered with an antic face,    To fleer and scorn at our solemnity?    Now, by the stock and honor of my kin,    To strike him dead I hold it not a sin.
dialogs.translated: By his voice I know that this man is a Montague.

dialogs.original: Why, how now, kinsman? Wherefore storm you so?
dialogs.translated: Whats all this, nephew? Why are you so furious?

dialogs.original: Uncle, this is a Montague, our foe,A villain that is hither come in spiteTo scorn at our solemnity this night.
dialogs.translated: Uncle, that is a Montagueour rival. Hes a rogue whos come here out of spite to scorn our celebration.

dialogs.original: Young Romeo is it?
dialogs.translated: Its young Romeo, right?

dialogs.original: Tis he, that villain Romeo.
dialogs.translated: Thats him, that villain Romeo.

dialogs.original: Content thee, gentle coz. Let him alone.    He bears him like a portly gentleman,    And, to say truth, Verona brags of him    To be a virtuous and well-governed youth.    I would not for the wealth of all the town    Here in my house do him disparagement.    Therefore be patient. Take no note of him.    It is my will, the which if thou respect,    Show a fair presence and put off these frowns,    An ill-beseeming semblance for a feast.
dialogs.translated: Calm yourself, gentle nephew. Leave him be. He holds himself like a gentleman of good manners, and, to be honest, everyone in Verona says that he is a virtuous and well-behaved youth. Not for all the wealth in this town would I insult him in my own house. Be calm. Pretend you never saw him. That is my command, and if you respect me, youll stop with all these frowns, which is no way to behave at a party.

dialogs.original: It fits when such a villain is a guest. Ill not endure him.
dialogs.translated: Its the way to behave when a scoundrel like him shows up. I wont stand him coming here.

dialogs.original: He shall be endured.    What, goodman boy! I say, he shall. Go to.    Am I the master here, or you? Go to.    Youll not endure him! God shall mend my soul,    Youll make a mutiny among my guests.    You will set cock-a-hoop. Youll be the man!
dialogs.translated: You will stand him. What, boy? I say you will. Get out of here. Am I the master here, or you? Get out. You wont stand him? God save my soul, youll start a riot among my guests! And youll crow like a rooster, like youre the man!

dialogs.original: Why, uncle, tis a shame.
dialogs.translated: But, uncle, were being dishonored.

dialogs.original: Go to, go to.    You are a saucy boy. Is t so, indeed?    This trick may chance to scathe you, I know what.    You must contrary me. Marry, tis time.    Well said, my hearts!   You are a princox, go.    Be quiet, or   More light, more light!   For shame!    Ill make you quiet.   What, cheerly, my hearts!
dialogs.translated: Come on, come on. Youre an impertinent boy. Is that really how you think it is? This silliness is likely to come back to harm you. I know what Im doing, but you feel the need to contradict me. Well, Ill show you a thing or two.

dialogs.original: Patience perforce with willful choler meeting    Makes my flesh tremble in their different greeting.    I will withdraw, but this intrusion shall    Now seeming sweet, convert to bitterest gall.
dialogs.translated: The blend of enforced restraint with my burning rage is making me tremble. Ill leave. But Ill make Romeo regret this prank, which at the moment seems to him like such great fun.

dialogs.original: [Taking JULIETs hand]   If I profane with my unworthiesthand    This holy shrine, the gentle sin is this:    My lips, two blushing pilgrims, ready stand    To smooth that rough touch with a tender kiss.
dialogs.translated: [Taking JULIETs hand] If I offend you by touching your holy hand with my own unworthy one, then my lips stand ready, like two blushing pilgrims, to smooth my rough touch with a gentle kiss.

dialogs.original: Good pilgrim, you do wrong your hand too much,    Which mannerly devotion shows in this,    For saints have hands that pilgrims hands do touch,    And palm to palm is holy palmers kiss.
dialogs.translated: Good pilgrim, you are unfair to your hand. Your hand shows proper devotion by touching mine, just as pilgrims reach out to touch the hands of saints. Holding palm to palm is like a pilgrims kiss.

dialogs.original: Have not saints lips, and holy palmers too?
dialogs.translated: Dont saints have lips? And pilgrims, too?

dialogs.original: Ay, pilgrim, lips that they must use in prayer.
dialogs.translated: Yes, pilgrimlips theyre supposed to use to pray.

dialogs.original: O, then, dear saint, let lips do what hands do.They pray; grant thou, lest faith turn to despair.
dialogs.translated: Oh, then, saint, let lips do what hands do: pray. Grant my prayer or my faith will turn to despair.

dialogs.original: Saints do not move, though grant for prayers sake.
dialogs.translated: Saints dont move, though they do grant prayers.

dialogs.original: Then move not, while my prayers effect I take.
dialogs.translated: Then remain still while I pray.

dialogs.original: Thus from my lips, by thine, my sin is purged.
dialogs.translated: Now your lips have cleaned the sin from mine.

dialogs.original: Then have my lips the sin that they have took.
dialogs.translated: Then my lips now have the sin they took from yours.

dialogs.original: Sin from thy lips? O trespass sweetly urged! Give me my sin again.
dialogs.translated: Sin from my lips? Oh, how you urge me on to another crime. Give me back my sin.

dialogs.original: You kiss by th book.
dialogs.translated: You kiss as if youve studied how.

dialogs.original: Madam, your mother craves a word with you.
dialogs.translated: Madam, your mother wants to speak with you.

dialogs.original: What is her mother?
dialogs.translated: Who is her mother?

dialogs.original: Marry, bachelor,    Her mother is the lady of the house,    And a good lady, and a wise and virtuous.    I nursed her daughter that you talked withal.    I tell you, he that can lay hold of her    Shall have the chinks.
dialogs.translated: Well, young man, her mother is the lady of the house. A good, wise, and virtuous lady. I nursed her daughter, who you were talking to just now. I tell you, the man who marries that girl will be rich.

dialogs.original: [Aside]  Is she a Capulet?O dear account! My life is my foes debt.
dialogs.translated: [To himself] Is she a Capulet? Oh, what a price Ive paid! My life is now owned by my enemy.

dialogs.original: [To ROMEO]  Away, begone. The sport is at the best.
dialogs.translated: [To ROMEO] Lets go, lets go, now while everything is still perfect.

dialogs.original: Ay, so I fear. The more is my unrest.
dialogs.translated: Yes, it is still perfect now. But Im afraid it will never be perfect again.

dialogs.original: Nay, gentlemen, prepare not to be gone.    We have a trifling foolish banquet towards.    Is it een so? Why, then, I thank you all.    I thank you, honest gentlemen. Good night.    More torches here!Come on then, lets to bed.    Ah, sirrah, by my fay, it waxes late.    Ill to my rest.
dialogs.translated: No, gentlemen, dont leave now. We have a bit of dessert arriving any moment. [They whisper something to him] Is that so? Then, I thank you. I thank you, honest gentlemen. Good night. Bring more torches over here! Come on, lets all get to bed.

dialogs.original: Come hither, Nurse. What is yond gentleman?
dialogs.translated: Come here, nurse. Who is that gentleman over there?

dialogs.original: The son and heir of old Tiberio.
dialogs.translated: The son and heir of old Tiberio.

dialogs.original: Whats he that now is going out of door?
dialogs.translated: Whos the one going out the door?

dialogs.original: Marry, that, I think, be young Petruchio.
dialogs.translated: That, I think, is young Petruchio.

dialogs.original: Whats he that follows here, that would not dance?
dialogs.translated: What about the one over there, who wouldnt dance?

dialogs.original: I know not.
dialogs.translated: I dont know him.

dialogs.original: Go ask his name.
dialogs.translated: Go ask him for his name.

dialogs.original: If he be married.My grave is like to be my wedding bed.
dialogs.translated: [To herself] If hes married, Id rather die than marry someone else.

dialogs.original: [Returning]  His name is Romeo, and a Montague,The only son of your great enemy.
dialogs.translated: [Returning] His name is Romeo. Hes a Montague. Hes the only son of your greatest enemy.

dialogs.original: [Aside]   My only love sprung from my only hate!    Too early seen unknown, and known too late!    Prodigious birth of love it is to me,    That I must love a loathèd enemy.
dialogs.translated: [To herself] The one man I love is the son of the one man I hate! I saw him before I knew who he was, and learned who he was too late! What a monster love is to make me love my worst enemy.

dialogs.original: Whats this? Whats this?
dialogs.translated: Whats this? Whats this?

dialogs.original: A rhyme I learned even nowOf one I danced withal.
dialogs.translated: A rhyme I learned just now from somebody I danced with.

dialogs.original: Anon, anon. Come, let's away. The strangers are all gone.
dialogs.translated: On our way, on our way! Come along, let's go. The strangers have all left.
